title: Bridge topic sentences to thesis
prompt: Rewrite each topic sentence so it clearly advances the thesis: 'Cities must rebalance transport investment.'
steps: Identify the paragraph's intended focus.
Name the benefit or consequence linking back to the thesis.
Draft a revised topic sentence in one line.
Check that the sentence signals progression (first, secondly, ultimately).

checks.input: Congestion pricing is controversial.
checks.target: Congestion pricing channels drivers toward transit, fulfilling the city's rebalancing goal.

checks.input: Bus routes could be improved.
checks.target: Prioritising bus-only corridors proves the city is shifting resources from private cars to mass transit.

takeaway: Every paragraph opener should echo the central decision cities must make.

title: Sharpen the thesis
prompt: Given a Task 2 question, craft a thesis that states your position and roadmap in 2 clauses.
steps: Underline the task command words.
List the two main reasons you will defend.
Combine them into a single, decisive sentence.
Check for hedging or vague verbs and replace them.

checks.question: Should public transport receive more funding than roads?
checks.weak: Governments should consider spending more on public transport.
checks.strong: Governments must divert future infrastructure budgets to metro and bus systems because they move more people with lower emissions.

takeaway: IELTS examiners reward clear, committed stances.

title: Evidence to anchor ideas
prompt: Pair each claim with a concrete statistic, study, or case. Avoid generic phrases like 'some people say'.
steps: Note the main claim.
Identify a real or plausible supporting example.
Write a 1-sentence illustration using numbers or proper nouns.
Explain how it proves the claim in 1 more sentence.

checks.question: Complete the example: 'Singapore's _________ shows that road pricing can reduce downtown traffic by 25%.'

takeaway: Specifics signal real-world awareness and strengthen Task Response.

title: Decisive conclusions
prompt: Draft a conclusion that synthesises reasons and issues a forward-looking recommendation.
steps: Restate the thesis using different wording.
Compress your two strongest reasons into a single compound sentence.
Add a call-to-action or forecast to close the essay.
Trim filler phrases (In conclusion, In summary).

checks.input: In conclusion, there are many reasons for this.
checks.target: Ultimately, cities that back rapid transit over highways will ease congestion and cut emissions, so budgets should follow commuters, not cars.

takeaway: A firm recommendation tells the examiner you addressed the question fully.

title: Two-minute outline sprint
prompt: Use the provided template to outline an essay in under two minutes.
steps: Write the thesis.
List two body topic sentences.
Add one evidence note per paragraph.
Sketch the conclusion action.
takeaway: A quick outline keeps Task Response on target under exam timing.

title: Upgrade cohesion markers
prompt: Replace basic linkers (and, but) with precise cohesive devices that show logic.
steps: Scan the paragraph for repeated basic linkers.
Choose an advanced linker category (result, contrast, concession).
Swap the linker and adjust punctuation if needed.
Read aloud to ensure flow is natural.

checks.input: Cars are convenient and they cause pollution.
checks.target: Cars are convenient; nevertheless, they intensify urban pollution.

checks.input: The metro is reliable and it is affordable.
checks.target: The metro is reliable; moreover, it remains affordable for commuters.

takeaway: Diverse cohesive devices raise your Cohesion & Coherence score.

title: Tighten reference chains
prompt: Replace vague pronouns with precise references to maintain clarity.
steps: Underline each pronoun in the paragraph.
Write the noun it refers to in the margin.
If unclear, replace the pronoun with a short noun phrase.
Check that successive sentences build on the same topic.

checks.question: Identify the ambiguous pronoun in 'This shows they care about it.'
checks.weak: This shows they care about it.
checks.strong: This response shows city planners care about efficient commuting.

takeaway: Clear reference chains prevent reader confusion.

title: One idea per paragraph
prompt: Reorganise mixed ideas into focused paragraphs with sequencing words.
steps: Highlight sentences covering different ideas.
Group sentences by idea and order them logically.
Add sequencing markers to show progression.
Rewrite the paragraph in the new order.
takeaway: Paragraph focus keeps your argument easy to follow.

title: Signpost the reader
prompt: Insert signposting phrases that preview paragraph content.
steps: Locate paragraphs lacking transitions.
Add a fronted clause that previews the argument.
Use sequencers like 'Turning to' or 'A further benefit is'.
Read aloud to ensure tone remains academic.

checks.input: Another point is that buses are cheap.
checks.target: Turning to affordability, bus networks remain accessible to low-income commuters.

takeaway: Signposting guides the examiner through your logic.

title: Task 1 flow words
prompt: Connect trends in a Task 1 overview using sequencing adverbs and comparatives.
steps: Identify the main stages or trends.
Assign a sequencing adverb (initially, subsequently, finally).
Link contrasting trends using 'whereas' or 'while'.
Write a polished overview paragraph.

checks.question: Complete: 'Initially, solar usage was low, ______ it surged after subsidies.'

takeaway: Cohesive sequencing lifts Task 1 organisation.

title: Upgrade collocations
prompt: Replace basic verb-noun combinations with precise collocations.
steps: Highlight generic verbs (make, do, get).
Brainstorm a stronger verb that matches the noun.
Swap the phrase and read aloud for tone.
Record two alternatives for future essays.

checks.input: make a decision
checks.target: reach a decision

checks.input: get better services
checks.target: secure better services

takeaway: Specific collocations show lexical resource range.

title: Synonym bands
prompt: Group synonyms by tone (neutral, formal, emphatic) and swap them into sample sentences.
steps: List three synonyms for each common adjective.
Label them by tone.
Rewrite sample sentences choosing the tone that fits the argument.
Check for repetition in neighbouring sentences.
takeaway: Tone-aware synonyms lift lexical variety.

title: Cut hedging phrases
prompt: Edit sentences to remove redundant hedging (maybe, kind of, really).
steps: Underline hedging phrases in each sentence.
Decide if evidence justifies a confident verb.
Replace with precise verbs or delete entirely.
Read aloud to ensure tone stays measured.

checks.input: It really might help traffic a lot.
checks.target: It will significantly reduce traffic.

takeaway: Confident wording strengthens arguments.

title: Rare word density
prompt: Revise a paragraph to include three topic-specific rare words naturally.
steps: List relevant domain vocabulary (e.g., 'congestion charge').
Select three that fit logically.
Rewrite sentences to integrate them without sounding forced.
Check grammar and tone.

checks.question: Insert a transport-specific term for 'price for drivers entering downtown'.

takeaway: Topic-specific lexis proves range.

title: Paraphrase the prompt
prompt: Transform the question statement using synonyms and grammar shifts without altering meaning.
steps: Highlight keywords in the prompt.
List synonyms or noun/verb conversions.
Rewrite the sentence using two changes.
Check the paraphrase retains the original meaning.

checks.question: 'Governments should invest more in public transport than roads.'
checks.weak: People think governments need to spend more on buses than roads.
checks.strong: Many argue authorities must reallocate infrastructure budgets toward mass transit rather than highways.

takeaway: A sophisticated paraphrase immediately signals lexical range.

title: Add complex sentences
prompt: Combine short sentences into complex ones using relative clauses or subordinators.
steps: Identify two short related sentences.
Choose a relative pronoun or subordinating conjunction.
Merge the sentences and adjust punctuation.
Check for subject-verb agreement.

checks.input: The city built new cycle lanes. They are safe.
checks.target: The city built new cycle lanes that are safe.

takeaway: Complex sentences showcase grammatical range.

title: Control tenses in Task 1
prompt: Review Task 1 sentences and ensure tense matches the timeline shown.
steps: Check whether the chart is past, present, or future.
Underline verbs and adjust tense accordingly.
Add time markers where missing.
Re-read to ensure consistency.

checks.input: In 2010, the city invests in buses.
checks.target: In 2010, the city invested in buses.

takeaway: Accurate tense control prevents grammar penalties.

title: Comma and semicolon control
prompt: Fix comma splices and run-ons in sample sentences.
steps: Identify independent clauses.
Choose to join with a semicolon, conjunction, or period.
Rewrite the sentence correctly.
Read aloud to confirm rhythm.

checks.input: People drive to work, the buses are unreliable.
checks.target: People drive to work because the buses are unreliable.

takeaway: Proper punctuation shows control at Band 7+.

title: Subject-verb agreement clinic
prompt: Spot agreement errors in transport-themed sentences and fix them.
steps: Underline the subject.
Decide if it is singular or plural.
Adjust the verb to match.
Check for compound subjects joined by 'and' or 'or'.

checks.question: Neither the buses nor the train ____ on time.

takeaway: Subject-verb agreement errors are costly at Band 6.

title: Article precision
prompt: Insert correct articles (a, an, the, zero) into transport-focused sentences.
steps: Identify whether the noun is specific or general.
Check for countability.
Choose the appropriate article or zero article.
Read aloud to ensure natural phrasing.

checks.question: ____ congestion charge was introduced last year.

takeaway: Article accuracy is a quick win for higher GRA scores.

title: Counterargument sandwich
prompt: Write a counterargument paragraph that concedes, refutes, and returns to your stance.
steps: State an opposing view fairly.
Acknowledge why it appeals to some people.
Use evidence to refute it.
Reaffirm why your stance still holds.

checks.input: Some say roads are faster. But I disagree.
checks.target: While some argue roads keep freight moving faster, data from Seoul shows bus rapid transit moves twice as many commuters per hour, so investment belongs on transit corridors.

takeaway: Balanced refutations strengthen Task Response band.

title: Decode question types
prompt: Categorise Task 2 prompts (opinion, discussion, problem/solution, advantages/disadvantages) and note the required moves.
steps: Underline directive words.
Assign the prompt to a pattern.
List paragraph functions.
Check your outline matches the pattern.
takeaway: Correct prompt typing avoids off-topic essays.

title: Task 1 overview laser
prompt: Write overview sentences that summarise the dominant trends in charts and diagrams.
steps: Identify the highest/lowest values.
Spot overall trends (increase, decrease, fluctuation).
Combine them into two concise sentences.
Avoid detailed numbers.

checks.question: Line chart of renewable energy rising in Germany and Spain, steady in Australia.
checks.weak: Germany and Spain go up but Australia is low.
checks.strong: Germany and Spain roughly tripled their renewable share, while Australia stayed comparatively flat.

takeaway: Strong overviews unlock higher Task 1 bands.

title: Timing splits
prompt: Practise allocating the 40-minute Task 2 window across planning, drafting, and revising.
steps: Set a 5-minute planning timer.
Write for 30 minutes.
Reserve 5 minutes to edit.
Note how long each stage actually took.
takeaway: Planning discipline preserves Task Response quality.

title: Hook the introduction
prompt: Draft introductions that paraphrase the question, state a thesis, and preview points in under 60 words.
steps: Paraphrase the prompt.
State your position.
Preview two key reasons.
Check word count under 60.
takeaway: Concise introductions save time for main paragraphs.

title: Transition bank sprint
prompt: Build a bank of advanced transitions for contrast, cause, and exemplification.
steps: Create three columns (contrast, cause, example).
List at least four transitions per column.
Write sample sentences using them.
Store favourites in your notes.
takeaway: Varied transitions prevent cohesion penalties.

title: Theme strings
prompt: Reorder sentences so that each new sentence picks up the theme from the previous clause.
steps: Identify the theme (topic) of each sentence.
Ensure the next sentence starts with that idea.
Rephrase where necessary to maintain flow.
Check the paragraph reads like a logical chain.
takeaway: Theme strings make paragraphs coherent.

title: Cohesive nouns
prompt: Swap repeated phrases with cohesive nouns (measure, initiative, approach) to avoid repetition.
steps: Highlight repeated nouns.
Select cohesive nouns to refer back to them.
Rewrite sentences using the cohesive noun.
Check pronoun agreement.

checks.input: The policy is helpful because the policy...
checks.target: The policy is helpful because this initiative ...

takeaway: Cohesive nouns tidy up repetition.

title: Sentence flow rescore
prompt: Insert linking clauses to smooth abrupt sentence jumps.
steps: Read sentences aloud to spot jumps.
Add participle clauses or fronted adverbs.
Ensure references stay clear.
Re-read for rhythm.

checks.input: Metro lines are frequent. People still drive.
checks.target: Although metro lines run every three minutes, many commuters still drive.

takeaway: Smooth flow boosts coherence scores.

title: Cohesion audit
prompt: Audit an essay for cohesion by checking transitions, references, and paragraph goals.
steps: Use a checklist covering linkers, references, and logical order.
Mark any missing connections.
Rewrite or insert linking phrases.
Summarise improvements.

items: Every paragraph has a clear topic sentence

takeaway: Systematic audits reveal hidden cohesion gaps.

title: Tone shift practice
prompt: Rewrite informal sentences in an academic tone without sounding robotic.
steps: Highlight slang or casual phrases.
Replace with formal equivalents.
Adjust sentence structure for clarity.
Read aloud to check flow.

checks.input: Cars are a total nightmare in rush hour.
checks.target: Private cars create severe congestion during peak hours.

takeaway: Formal tone suits IELTS academic tasks.

title: Field vocabulary notes
prompt: Collect domain-specific vocabulary sets (transport, environment, education) with definitions and sample sentences.
steps: Pick a domain.
List five advanced nouns/verbs/adjectives.
Write definitions and example sentences.
Review and test yourself later.

checks.question: Term for 'a charge for entering city centres'

takeaway: Thematic vocabulary boosts lexical resource.

title: Word family switch
prompt: Convert root words into different forms (noun, verb, adjective, adverb) and use them in sentences.
steps: Write the root word.
Generate each word form.
Create sentences relevant to transport.
Check collocation accuracy.
takeaway: Word-family agility widens lexical options.

title: Precise metaphors
prompt: Replace clichéd metaphors with precise imagery rooted in the topic.
steps: Identify the cliché.
Brainstorm imagery connected to transport.
Rewrite the sentence.
Ensure meaning stays literal enough for IELTS.

checks.input: Traffic is a double-edged sword.
checks.target: Traffic is a knot that slows every bus heading downtown.

takeaway: Fresh imagery keeps language vivid without risking misinterpretation.

title: Lexical cohesion sets
prompt: Create lexical sets for key themes and ensure they appear across a paragraph to reinforce cohesion.
steps: Choose a theme (e.g., public transport).
List related terms (ridership, fare cap, dwell time).
Write a paragraph using at least three terms.
Highlight how they reinforce the theme.

checks.question: Word meaning 'time a train stops at a station'

takeaway: Lexical sets help examiners see topic control.

title: Relative clause ladder
prompt: Transform simple sentences by embedding relative clauses to add detail.
steps: Pick a noun that could take a clause.
Add who/which/that clauses with extra information.
Ensure commas are used correctly.
Read aloud to confirm clarity.

checks.input: The train was delayed. It broke down.
checks.target: The train, which broke down, was delayed.

takeaway: Relative clauses show syntactic range.

title: Precise modals
prompt: Select modals that express obligation, possibility, or prediction accurately.
steps: Identify the intended strength of the claim.
Choose an appropriate modal (must, should, could, is likely to).
Rewrite the sentence.
Check consistency with evidence.
takeaway: Accurate modals prevent examiner confusion.

title: Inversion emphasis
prompt: Practise inversion structures (Not only..., Rarely..., Had ...) to add emphasis appropriately.
steps: Rewrite sentences beginning with inversion.
Ensure auxiliary verbs are placed before the subject.
Use commas where necessary.
Keep tone formal.

checks.input: People rarely consider bus frequency.
checks.target: Rarely do people consider bus frequency.

takeaway: Advanced structures like inversion demonstrate grammatical range.

title: Conditional accuracy
prompt: Fix mixed conditional errors and ensure verbs match the scenario.
steps: Decide if the condition is real, hypothetical, or past.
Choose the correct tense pair.
Rewrite the sentence.
Check punctuation.

checks.input: If cities invested last year, traffic will reduce.
checks.target: If cities had invested last year, traffic would have reduced.

takeaway: Conditional control is essential for Band 7+.

title: Parallel structure polish
prompt: Edit sentences so listed items follow the same grammatical form.
steps: Identify lists or paired ideas.
Check each element uses the same grammatical pattern.
Rewrite to align forms.
Read aloud for rhythm.

checks.input: The policy aims to cut costs, improving safety, and to attract riders.
checks.target: The policy aims to cut costs, improve safety, and attract riders.

takeaway: Parallel structures keep sentences balanced.
